abstract.p: Ann Moritz Chesnut letter on July 2 article views as disturbing thousands of dollars dermatologist Dr David Bank spends each year on publicist6

block.p: Since I am a newsletter editor and communications coordinator for a national voluntary health agency, ''Doctors Who Love Publicity'' looked like a fascinating piece.
Then I read the photo caption and my fascination turned to dismay.
Since I am a newsletter editor and communications coordinator for a national voluntary health agency, ''Doctors Who Love Publicity'' looked like a fascinating piece.
Then I read the photo caption and my fascination turned to dismay.
It turned out that the doctor in question, Dr. David Bank, is the head of the dermatology practice that my family and I have patronized regularly for a number of years.
The partner whom we routinely visit appears to be a thorough and conscientious physician, and we have been very happy with the care provided.

However, we have noticed lately a proliferation of laminated magazine clippings on display, stacks of high-end women's magazines with Post-it note markers indicating the places where Dr. Bank is quoted, a lot of printed information on chemical peels and liposuction, and an emphasis on cosmetic surgery in general, not to mention an obviously costly renovation and reorganization of the office space.

The fact that Dr. Bank spends thousands of dollars a year on a publicist is disturbing to me, because it inevitably means that he needs to see more patients and/or charge higher fees in order to meet this added expense.

It is significant to me that during one visit I remember having with Dr. Bank himself, he encouraged me to consider a costly chemical process that is not covered by health insurance, a process that the partner I routinely see had never felt compelled to mention.

There is no question in my mind that Dr. Bank and his associates are dedicated and competent doctors, but I am nevertheless concerned to learn that he has set his sights far above the middle-class, run-of-the-mill skin woes that my family bring to Mount Kisco.
ANN MORITZ CHESNUT Lake Peekskill, N.Y.
